bestBHT.bht: In one of the most powerful miracles performed by Jesus, he raises the servant to wholeness. This event stands among the three greatest recorded miracles in the Bible, which include the resurrections of Jairus's daughter and Lazarus. The Greek term used, υγιαινοντα, signifies the complete restoration of the servant to full health. This emphasizes the remarkable healing power displayed by Jesus, highlighting his boundless compassion and ability to bring about miraculous transformations.

Henry Alford: This is one of the three greatest recorded miracles of our Lord.
He raised one (Jairus’s daughter) when just dead,—one on the way to burial,—and one (Lazarus) who had been buried four days.
Marvin Vincent: Whole [υγιαινοντα] . See on ch. Luke 5:31. The best texts omit that had been sick.
Philip Schaff: Luke 7:10. Found the servant whole, or, ‘well.’ Luke here carries out the detail of his narrative.
John Gill: And they that were sent, returning to the house, found the servant whole that had been sick."
For he was healed directly, as soon as the centurion had expressed his faith.
Christ had declared that it should be according to it.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this particular account, it is said to be one of the greatest miracles performed by Jesus. Interestingly, this verse appears to be part of a series of recorded miracles, with two other significant examples being the resurrection of Jairus's daughter and Lazarus. The specific Greek term used in the verse, υγιαινοντα, refers to the servant being sound or well, emphasizing the complete restoration of his health. Luke, the author of this Gospel, provides added emphasis on the servant's condition by mentioning that the servant was whole rather than simply well.

In this extraordinary account, Jesus performs one of his most remarkable miracles. It is remarkable because it is included among the three greatest miracles recorded of Jesus, which include raising Jairus's daughter and Lazarus. The Greek term used in the passage, υγιαινοντα, signifies complete soundness and wellness, emphasizing the entirety of the servant's healing. Its distinct usage underscores the restoration of the servant's health. This demonstrates the magnitude of Jesus' power and compassion in bringing about miraculous healing.

In one of the most powerful miracles performed by Jesus, he raises the servant to wholeness. This event stands among the three greatest recorded miracles in the Bible, which include the resurrections of Jairus's daughter and Lazarus. The Greek term used, υγιαινοντα, signifies the complete restoration of the servant to full health. This emphasizes the remarkable healing power displayed by Jesus, highlighting his boundless compassion and ability to bring about miraculous transformations.

In one of the greatest miracles of Jesus, he raises the servant to complete wellness. This stands alongside the resurrections of Jairus's daughter and Lazarus as exceptional displays of Jesus' divine power. The Greek term used, υγιαινοντα, denotes the servant's soundness and well-being. This emphasizes the significance of the servant's complete healing, demonstrating Jesus' immense compassion and ability to bring about extraordinary transformations.

In this notable display of Jesus' power, he performs one of the three most extraordinary recorded miracles. It is remarkable that Jesus raises the servant to full health, just as he resurrected Jairus's daughter and Lazarus. The Greek term used in the verse, υγιαινοντα, signifies the servant's soundness and well-being. This choice of word emphasizes the complete restoration of the servant's health, highlighting Jesus' remarkable ability to bring about profound healing.
